acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute
acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Since its 96h-LC50 = 0.0008 mg/L for fish (bluegills) (ECOTOX, 2008), the substance was classified into Category 1.

acute_toxicity_dermal.rationale: A dermal test using rats showed LD50 >= 10000 mg/kg bw (EHC 92, 1989; JMPR 356, 1976), which is equivalent to the guidance values (JIS, >= 2000 mg/kg bw; GHS, >= 5000 mg/kg bw) of "Not classified".

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists
acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.rationale: A inhalation test on rats (EHC 92, 1989; JMPR 356, 1976), with unknown exposure route, is considered to be conducted with the substance in the form of a mist or powder, because the vapour pressure is reported to be 0.00014 mmHg (25degC) (reference document, SRC (accessed June 2008)). However, since the LC50 >= 0.872 mg/L (for 24 hours), which is >= 0.145 mg/L (for four hours), and is equivalent to the guidance values of Category 2 - Not classified, classification is not possible.

acute_toxicity_inhalation_gas.rationale:
Solid (GHS definition)
Since its melting point is 30 - 35degC and the substance is a viscous oil or paste (ICSC (J), 2001), its physicochemical hazard as a liquid was also considered.

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Documented rat LD50 values consist of the same number of data of 675 mg/kg (EHC 92 (1989); original literature, 1986), 840 mg/kg (original literature, 1984), 990 mg/kg (original literature, 1979), 7071 mg/kg (original literature, 1970), > 8000 mg/kg (original literature, 1972), and 8800 mg/kg (original literature, 1969), which are equivalent to the guidance values of "Not classified" (>= 2000 mg/kg bw), and 675 - 990 mg/kg bw (EHC 92, 1989; EHC (J) 92, 1990) which are equivalent to the guidance values of Category 4 (300 - 2000 mg/kg bw). Thus, data with later original literatures were adopted and the substance was classified into Category 4.

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_statement: Very toxic to aquatic life with long lasting effects
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Since its preexisting classification for acute toxicity is Category 1 and it is not rapidly degradable (SRC: BioWin V4.10), the substance was classified into Category 1.

explosives.rationale: There are no chemical groups associated with explosive properties present in the molecules.

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases

flammable_liquids.rationale: The substance is a solid (GHS definition), and is considered to be a very viscous liquid at room temperature. Since its flash point is 92degC (Pesticide Manual, 14th, 2006), it is equivalent to the guidance value of Category 4.

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Since the substance was positive in a mutagenicity test (rat micronucleus test) (ATSDR, 2003), it was classified into Category 2.

organic_peroxides.rationale: Organic compounds containing no bivalent -O-O- structure in the molecule

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: The substance is a solid (GHS definition), and is considered to be a very viscous liquid at room temperature. The substance contains oxygen (but not fluorine or chlorine), which is chemically bonded only to carbon or hydrogen.

oxidizing_solids.rationale: The substance is a solid (GHS definition), and is considered to be a very viscous liquid at room temperature. The substance contains oxygen (but not fluorine or chlorine), which is chemically bonded only to carbon or hydrogen.

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: The substance is a solid (GHS definition), and is considered to be a very viscous liquid at room temperature. Since its flash point is 92degC (Pesticide Manual, 14th, 2006), it is equivalent to the guidance value of Not classified.

reproductive_toxicity.hazard_statement: May damage fertility or the unborn child
reproductive_toxicity.rationale: Since it was documented that in a rabbit test, there was no apparent effect on parents in the study, a large amount of resorption was noted at all treatment levels (EHC 92, 1989; JMPR 356, 1976), the substance was classified into Category 1B.

self_heating_substances.rationale: Test methods applicable to solid (melting point <= 140degC) substances are not available.

self_reactive_substances.rationale: There are no chemical groups present in the molecule associated with explosive or self-reactive properties.

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Since it is documented in a rabbit test that instillation of the substance did not produce any irritation or corneal damage, or any indication of ocular hazard (EHC 92, 1989; JMPR 356, 1976), it was classified into "Not classified".

skin_sensitizer.rationale: Since it is documented in a guinea pig test that the substance showed only traces of erythema suggesting a low potential for sensitization and irritation (EHC 92, 1989; JMPR 356, 1976), and the test did not conclude its skin sensitization, the substance was classified into "Classification not possible".

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: The chemical structure of the substance does not contain metals or metalloids (B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At).

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: It was documented that in a oral administration test using rats for 91 days, fatty infiltration of the liver was noticed at 1200 mg/kg diet or higher, when converted, the dose is 60 mg/kg/day bw (EHC 92, 1989; EHC (J) 92, 1990; JMPR 356, 1976). In addition, in an oral administration test using dogs for 90 days, the NOAEL was 80 mg/kg, and no adverse effects were observed on histopathological examination, although effects on blood system were seen at 250 mg/kg (EHC 92, 1989). Thus, the substance was classified into "Classification not possible".

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_statement: May cause drowsiness or dizziness (narcotic effects)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: Two hours after oral administration, the animal went into spasms, became nervous toward other animals and aggressive. Finally, the animal experienced spasms, weakening, coma, and died within 24 hours. Since the substance showed neurotoxicity at doses above the guidance value, it was classified into Category 3 (narcotic effects).
